HDFS138.name: Introduction to Financial Literacy
HDFS138.description: Design, develop, and integrate a comprehensive plan to achieve financial goals. Topics will have an immediate impact on everyday life to achieve financial freedom and success.

HDFS145.name: The Individual, Couples and Families
HDFS145.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HDFS145.description: Development of the young adult in the human ecological context. Issues of sexuality, gender, parenting, work and family interface, communication, and resource use. Diversity in relationships and families.

HDFS201.name: Child Development (ages 0-3)
HDFS201.description: Theories and research of development; physical, cognitive, social-emotional, aesthetic and adult’s role for ages 0-3.

HDFS206.name: Practicum I: Child Observations in Classroom Environments
HDFS206.description: Guided learning experiences in a professional agency, use of theories and practices developed in human development and family studies courses.

HDFS211.name: Child Growth and Development
HDFS211.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HDFS211.description: Physical, cognitive, social, emotional, and ecological aspects of human growth and development from conception through early childhood.

HDFS212.name: Children, Youth and Family
HDFS212.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HDFS212.description: An ecosystems perspective on development during childhood and adolescence emphasizing family and community contexts.

HDFS225.name: Lifespan Human Development in the Family
HDFS225.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HDFS225.description: Human development in the family and across the lifespan with an ecological perspective. Relationships between human resource professionals and family systems.

HDFS238.name: Personal Finance
HDFS238.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HDFS238.description: Strategies, techniques, and resources for the management of personal finance.

HDFS270.name: Introduction to Human Development and Family Studies
HDFS270.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HDFS270.description: Introduction of ecological perspective for Human Service delivery. Professional orientation, ethics and factors influencing the field. Participation in service learning required.
HDFS270.restrictions: Open to students in the Department of Human Development and Family Studies.

HDFS303.name: Assessment and Observations in Early Care and Education
HDFS303.description: Selection and use of culturally sensitive assessments across developmental domains to inform interventions.
HDFS303.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students in the Early Care and Education Major.

HDFS304.name: Understanding and Adapting for Developmental Differences in Early Care and Education
HDFS304.description: Knowledge of disability conditions, assessment and identification, interventions in inclusive environments, collaborations among service providers.

HDFS320.name: Interaction with Children in Groups
HDFS320.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HDFS320.description: Principles of verbal and non-verbal interaction in relation to children's behavior in groups. Focus on young children in early childhood programs.
HDFS320.restrictions: Open to students in the Department of Human Development and Family Studies.

HDFS320L.name: Interaction with Children-Laboratory
HDFS320L.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HDFS320L.description: Practice applying principles of interaction to individuals and small groups in early childhood programs.
HDFS320L.restrictions: Open to students in the Department of Human Development and Family Studies.

HDFS321.name: Curriculum for Children (W)
HDFS321.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HDFS321.description: Child development principles and accreditation standards for designing curricula for early childhood programs. Planning and evaluating learning activities and programs.
HDFS321.prerequisite: (HDFS 320) and completion of Tier I writing requirement
HDFS321.restrictions: Open to students in the Department of Human Development and Family Studies.

HDFS321L.name: Curriculum for Children - Laboratory
HDFS321L.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HDFS321L.description: Supervised practice in providing learning activities for individual children and small groups. Planning, implementing, and evaluating activities. Field trips may be required.
HDFS321L.restrictions: Open to students in the Department of Human Development and Family Studies.

HDFS322.name: Infant Development and Program Planning
HDFS322.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HDFS322.description: Markers of typical and atypical development in infancy. Indicators of quality childcare. Early intervention and support programs. Issues in curriculum and environments of childcare.

HDFS322L.name: Interaction and Curriculum for Infants and Toddlers–Laboratory
HDFS322L.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HDFS322L.description: Applying principles of interaction to individuals and small groups of infants and toddlers in early childhood settings. Planning developmentally supportive learning opportunities. Supervised practice implementing and evaluating individualized learning opportunities in group care and education settings.
HDFS322L.restrictions: Open to students in the Department of Human Development and Family Studies.

HDFS345.name: Principles of Family Studies (W)
HDFS345.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HDFS345.description: Historical, social, cultural, and economic perspectives on contemporary families. Approaches to studying families. Role of communication, resources, and decision-making in family systems.
HDFS345.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement and HDFS 270
HDFS345.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Department of Human Development and Family Studies.

HDFS406.name: Practicum III: Capstone Experience (W)
HDFS406.description: Guided learning experiences in a professional agency, use of theories and practices related to lesson planning and implementation, assessment, classroom environments.
HDFS406.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

HDFS412.name: Ecological Perspective of Adolescents
HDFS412.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HDFS412.description: Cross-disciplinary and cross-cultural perspectives on today’s youth. Health and nutrition, substance abuse, risk taking, violence and neglect, homelessness, juvenile crime and justice, media and technology and balancing resources.
HDFS412.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students in the College of Social Science.

HDFS414.name: Parenting
HDFS414.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HDFS414.description: Childrearing in modern society. Adult parenting roles in various family structures. Support roles of families and communities.
HDFS414.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students.

HDFS421.name: Assessment of the Young Child
HDFS421.description: Selection of appropriate assessment instruments for children from birth through age 8 across developmental domains. Use of data to inform decisions about teaching and intervention. Assessment topics include ethical collection, evaluation, use of data; multicultural sensitivity; reliability and validity of measures; and assessment of children with special needs.
HDFS421.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students in the Department of Human Development and Family Studies.

HDFS424.name: Student Teaching in an Early Childhood Program
HDFS424.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HDFS424.description: Supervised teaching practicum. Planning, implementing, and evaluating an ecological educational program for children and their families.
HDFS424.restrictions: Open to students in the Department of Human Development and Family Studies. Approval of department.

HDFS442.name: Ethnic Families in America
HDFS442.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HDFS442.description: Historical, structural, and functional components of selected ethnic minority family systems in America. Lifestyles, pressures, adaptations, viability, and continuity.
HDFS442.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students.

HDFS444.name: Interpersonal Relationships in the Family
HDFS444.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HDFS444.description: Personal awareness and interpersonal relationships within the family system.
HDFS444.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students.

HDFS445.name: Human Sexuality
HDFS445.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HDFS445.description: Family and psychosocial factors affecting the development of a person's sexuality across the life cycle. Reciprocal impact on society and the legal system.
HDFS445.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students.

HDFS447.name: Management of Human Service Programs
HDFS447.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HDFS447.description: Analysis of family and community service programs and organizations. Effective management and leadership processes. Programs and organizations from an ecological perspective.
HDFS447.restrictions: Open to students in the Department of Human Development and Family Studies.

HDFS448.name: Child and Family Policy
HDFS448.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HDFS448.description: Issues faced by American families and children. Relationships among social science research, theory, and public policy.
HDFS448.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students.

HDFS449.name: Special Needs Children and Their Families
HDFS449.description: Resources and interventions available to families and community agencies. Implications for family decisions and professional practices, decisions, and actions.
HDFS449.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students.

HDFS454.name: Family Resource Management
HDFS454.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HDFS454.description: Resource management strategies of families during the life cycle, including time, money, material assets, energy, social connections,and space.
HDFS454.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students in the Department of Human Development and Family Studies.

HDFS472.name: Evaluation of Human Service Programs
HDFS472.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HDFS472.description: Evaluation design, methodology, and implementation with applications to family, child, consumer, and human service-related programs. Interactions of individuals, families, and human-service programs from perspectives of family ecology.
HDFS472.restrictions: Open to seniors or graduate students in the Department of Human Development and Family Studies.

HDFS473.name: Administration of Early Childhood Programs
HDFS473.description: Administrator's role in early childhood programs. Ecological focus on administrative relationships, regulations, fiscal and management skills, and developmentally appropriate practices.
HDFS473.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students in the Department of Human Development and Family Studies.

HDFS481.name: Research and Quantitative Methods in Human Development and Family Studies
HDFS481.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HDFS481.description: Survey of qualitative and quantitative research methods. Evaluate, conceptualize and plan research. Validity and ethics explored for consumers of research in community agencies.
HDFS481.prerequisite: (HDFS 270) and ((MTH 103 or MTH 110 or MTH 116 or MTH 124 or MTH 132 or STT 200 or STT 201 or MTH 101 or MTH 102) or designated score on Mathematics Placement test )
HDFS481.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students in the Department of Human Development and Family Studies.

HDFS490.name: Independent Study
HDFS490.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HDFS490.description: Individual study of selected topics under faculty guidance.
HDFS490.restrictions: Not open to sophomores or freshmen. Approval of department; application required.

HDFS490H.name: Honors Independent Study
HDFS490H.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HDFS490H.description: Honors individual study of selected topics with faculty guidance.
HDFS490H.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores. Approval of department; application required.

HDFS493.name: Internship
HDFS493.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HDFS493.description: Professional experience in a community organization.
HDFS493.restrictions: Open to seniors in the Department of Human Development and Family Studies. Approval of department.

HDFS497.name: Topics in Human Development and Family Studies
HDFS497.description: Topics in the areas of infancy, childhood, youth, aging, or family.

HDFS810.name: Theories of Human Development
HDFS810.description: Major theories of development; research findings and the validity of theoretical positions.

HDFS811.name: Child Development: Ecological Perspectives
HDFS811.description: Ecological factors that influence family functioning and child outcomes.

HDFS812.name: Adolescence in the Family: Ecological Perspectives
HDFS812.description: Ecological factors that influence family functioning and adolescent outcomes.

HDFS813.name: Adulthood and Aging in the Family: Ecological Perspectives
HDFS813.description: Adult development and aging in the contexts of family and community. Family relationships in adulthood and aging.

HDFS814.name: Parenthood and Parent Education
HDFS814.description: Influence of parents on children/youth and factors that influence parenting; approaches to providing education and support for parents.

HDFS817.name: Advanced Practice in Infant and Toddler Early Childhood Programming
HDFS817.description: Indicators of developmentally appropriate practices in infant and toddler programming including individualized and culturally sensitive practices with infants, toddlers, and families, research-informed practice, early learning environments, methods and materials, partnerships with families, reflective supervision, infant/toddler and program assessment, and professional development of staff. Observation and interactive experiences required.

HDFS818.name: Advanced Curricular Adaptations in Diverse Early Childhood Environments
HDFS818.description: Child development principles and accreditation standards for designing curricula for diverse early childhood programs. Strong emphasis on planning and evaluating learning activities and programs.

HDFS819.name: Advanced Teaching Practicum in an Early Childhood Program
HDFS819.description: Child development principles and accreditation standards for designing curricula for diverse early childhood programs; emphasis on planning and evaluating learning activities and programs. A daily practicum experience involving planning, implementing, and evaluating activities in an early childhood setting.

HDFS820.name: Infant Development: The Contexts of Family, Community, and Culture
HDFS820.description: Development from conception through age three. Family and community environments as contexts for development. Cultural influences on development, parenting goals, and community practices. Infants in poverty. Issues in sensitive assessment. Culturally inclusive research in infancy.

HDFS821.name: Prevention, Intervention and Educational Programs in Early Childhood
HDFS821.description: Theory, content, evaluation of early childhood prevention, intervention and educational programs. Early childhood policies and practices. Research methods.

HDFS822.name: Assessment of the Young Child
HDFS822.description: Assessment instruments and procedures for children from birth to age seven. Techniques for assessing physical, social, emotional, and cognitive development of young children.

HDFS825.name: Families with Special Needs Children: An Ecological Perspective
HDFS825.description: Partnerships between professionals and families to serve children with disabilities.

HDFS826.name: Social-Emotional Development Birth to Eight Years: Biology, Relationships, and Culture
HDFS826.description: Theory and research on social-emotional development birth to eight. Variability and diversity influenced by biology, family, relationships, and culture.

HDFS827.name: Language and Literacy Development from Infancy to Formal Schooling
HDFS827.description: Theoretical, empirical, multidisciplinary perspectives on language/literacy birth to school transition. Relationship between language and literacy. Integration of research, practice, policy

HDFS830.name: Survey of Couple and Family Therapy Theories
HDFS830.description: Contemporary theories of couple and family therapy.

HDFS842.name: African American Families
HDFS842.description: Historical and contemporary approaches to the study of African and African American families. Major theoretical frameworks.

HDFS845.name: Foundations of Family Study
HDFS845.description: Historical and cultural perspectives on the family. Conceptual approaches to family study. Sensitivity to family diversity. Key issues related to the life cycle.

HDFS847.name: Theories of the Family
HDFS847.description: Perspectives on the family. Relationships of theory, research, and practice.

HDFS860.name: Youth Policy and Positive Youth Development
HDFS860.description: Federal and state policies and their relationship to youth development.

HDFS861.name: Community Youth Development
HDFS861.description: Asset or strength-based community model for youth development. Holistic and dynamic understanding of youth and communities. Individual development. Adolescents' interrelationships with their environments.

HDFS862.name: Youth Cultures and the Culture of Youth
HDFS862.description: Contextual and cultural factors, historical and societal influences that shape contemporary beliefs and attitudes of and toward youth. Ways in which adults engage youth in formal and informal settings.
HDFS862.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Youth Development major.

HDFS864.name: Foundations of Youth Development
HDFS864.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HDFS864.description: Theories, concepts and terminology of youth development. Ethical, professional, and historical elements of youth development in social, economic, ethnic and political contexts.
HDFS864.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Youth Development major.

HDFS865.name: Capstone GPIDEA
HDFS865.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HDFS865.description: Independent research for faculty and peer feedback on research projects.

HDFS874.name: Foundations and Principles of Family Community Services
HDFS874.description: Theory, research and practice with families in community contexts.
HDFS874.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Human Development and Family Studies.

HDFS875.name: Resilience in Families
HDFS875.description: Models of family resilience across life span and within special populations, such as families in crisis, culturally diverse families, and military families.
HDFS875.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Human Development and Family Studies.

HDFS880.name: Research Design and Measurement
HDFS880.description: Methods applied to problem definition, research design, and analysis in Human Development and Family Studies.

HDFS881.name: Quantitative Methods in Human Development
HDFS881.description: Application of quantitative techniques to the analysis of human development and family studies research data.
HDFS881.restrictions: Open to master''s students or doctoral students in the Department of Human Development and Family Studies.

HDFS888.name: Diverse Families and Communities: Interventions and Strategies
HDFS888.description: Diversity in families and communities. Culturally sensitive interventions and strategies delivered by culturally competent therapists.

HDFS890.name: Master's Independent Study
HDFS890.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HDFS890.description: Individual study of selected topics with faculty guidance.
HDFS890.restrictions: Open to master's students or approval of department.

HDFS892.name: Seminar in Human Development and Family Studies
HDFS892.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HDFS892.description: Selected content in family relationships, family economics, human development in the family, community services, or programs for children and families.

HDFS894.name: Laboratory and Field Experience
HDFS894.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HDFS894.restrictions: Open to master's students or doctoral students in the Department of Human Development and Family Studies.

HDFS895.name: Families in Poverty
HDFS895.description: Causes of poverty. Poverty and family functioning. Proposals for breaking the poverty cycle.

HDFS899.name: Master's Thesis Research
HDFS899.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HDFS899.restrictions: Open to master's students in the Department of Human Development and Family Studies.

HDFS901.name: Contemporary Scholarship in Human Development and Family Studies
HDFS901.description: Multiple perspectives on human development and family studies scholarship. Emerging research; professional development strategies.
HDFS901.restrictions: Open to doctoral students in the Department of Human Development and Family Studies.

HDFS903.name: Evidence-based Couple and Family Therapy Intervention Programs
HDFS903.description: In-depth review of couple and family therapy intervention programs with strong evidence of effectiveness.

HDFS910.name: Contemporary Couple and Family Therapy Theories
HDFS910.description: Emerging theories and issues related to couple and family therapy. Review of evidence based family-based interventions.

HDFS911.name: Outcome Research: What Works in Couple and Family Therapy Theories
HDFS911.description: Common and unique change processes in couple and family therapy. Review of common factors and other non-technique approaches to change.

HDFS924.name: Quantitative Observational Methods for Studying Behavior and Development
HDFS924.description: Methodologies for observational research in study of human behavior and development. Measurement design and application, reliability and validity, analysis of resulting data.

HDFS960.name: Applied Multivariate Data Analysis
HDFS960.description: Application of quantitative techniques to the analysis of multivariate data.
HDFS960.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Human Development and Family Studies.

HDFS961.name: Applied Structural Equation Modeling
HDFS961.description: Application of structural equation models to data analysis.
HDFS961.restrictions: Open to doctoral students in the Department of Human Development and Family Studies or in the Department of Psychology.

HDFS962.name: Longitudinal Structural Equation Modeling
HDFS962.description: Application of structural equation modeling to the analysis of longitudinal data.
HDFS962.restrictions: Open to doctoral students in the Department of Human Development and Family Studies or in the Department of Psychology.

HDFS982.name: Qualitative Research Methods
HDFS982.description: Theoretical and applied experience related to qualitative research design and methodology.
HDFS982.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Human Development and Family Studies.

HDFS983.name: Advanced Methods in Intervention Research
HDFS983.description: Methodological issues. Research design, measurement, and analysis appropriate for assessing effectiveness of couple and family therapy. Development of a couple and family therapy research proposal.

HDFS990.name: Doctoral Independent Study
HDFS990.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HDFS990.description: Individual study of selected topics with faculty guidance.
HDFS990.restrictions: Open to doctoral students in the Department of Human Development and Family Studies or approval of department.

HDFS993.name: Internship
HDFS993.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HDFS993.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Human Development and Family Studies. Approval of department.

HDFS994.name: Advanced Evidence-Based Couple Therapy
HDFS994.description: In-depth study of evidence-based couple therapy.
HDFS994.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Human Development and Family Studies. Approval of department.

HDFS995.name: Couple and Family Therapy Supervision
HDFS995.description: Models of couple and family therapy and related supervision principles. Development of perceptual, cognitive, and executive supervisory skills. Ethical, legal, and educational issues.
HDFS995.restrictions: Open to doctoral students in the Department of Human Development and Family Studies. Approval of department.

HDFS999.name: Doctoral Dissertation Research
HDFS999.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HDFS999.restrictions: Open to doctoral students in the Department of Human Development and Family Studies.
